channel.title: Iphones Siri tells 12 year old boy to "Shut the fuck up you ugly twat"
channel.description:
HAHAHAHA, it was the answer it gave for the question "how many people are there in the world?"
For all the kind and helpful advice that Apple's Siri personal assistant gives out, don't ever catch it on a bad day, or it'll tell you off in ways your mother would not approve. If a report from The Sun is to be believed, a demo unit for the iPhone 4S caught fire for telling 12-year-old Charle Le Quesne to "Shut the f--- up, you ugly t---." Charlie reportedly asked Siri "How many people are there in the world?" and that was the answer he got back. Together with his mother and the manager, they asked the demo iPhone 4S the same question and got the same answer back yet again. Needless to say, the demo unit was unplugged and sent back to Apple for "diagnostic tests." The errors seems to have stemmed from Siri thinking that the questioner's name was "Shut the f--- up, you ugly t---." All this happened at a U.K. Tesco supermarket. It's worth noting that on U.K. iPhones, Siri's default voice is that of a male and not female like it is in the U.S. So you'll have to picture Siri cursing the poor boy out with a male British accent. I bet it sounds even funnier that way.

item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

It’s pretty easy to do and it isn’t an actual response from the phone. You set your information by a contact in your phone, so your contact where you can set various information about yourself, who your siblings and parents are.

It uses the title of that contact as a name for you, and it’ll sometimes reply with your name, then the information. What was done here, is someone labeled the contact which the phone was set to as “Shut the fuck up, you ugly twat” and it read that out.

It was explained in one of the early reporting of the story but various journalists are conveniently leaving it out because it isn’t all that interesting otherwise.

Also:

It's worth noting that on U.K. iPhones, Siri's default voice is that of a male and not female like it is in the U.S. So you'll have to picture Siri cursing the poor boy out with a male British accent. I bet it sounds even funnier that way.

It still pronounces it like an American though. “Twot”.
